DOC.HEAD: Begins Production
DOC.TEXT: Honda of America on Monday began mass production of Civics at its new plant, a 1.4 million-square-foot operation in west-central Ohio about five miles from the automaker's first assembly plant at Marysville. The Japanese-owned company, now the fourth-largest automaker in the United States, said it will make 65,000 cars at the new plant next year. In 1991, the company expects the plant to produce 150,000 cars, bringing Honda's total auto production in Ohio to 510,00 Accords and Civics that year. The Marysville plant, about 3.1 million square feet, also makes Civic four-door sedans, as well as Accord four-door sedans and two-door coupes. It produces 360,000 cars a year. Honda said the $380 million East Liberty plant has 450 employees working one shift during the remaining five days of production this year. At full production, the plant will have about 1,800 employees on two shifts. The company said the plant will help meet its production needs for exporting cars. Honda plans to increase exports to Japan and other countries from about 12,000 cars this year to 70,000 in the early 1990s.
